entry.title: Azerbaijan‚Äôs top diplomat warns Armenia‚Äôs ‚Äòmilitarization‚Äô threatens normalization talks

media:group.media:title: Azerbaijan‚Äôs top diplomat warns Armenia‚Äôs ‚Äòmilitarization‚Äô threatens normalization talks
media:group.media:description:
üìç Senior Azerbaijani officials reiterated that signing a normalization deal hinges on Armenia removing indirect references to Nagorno-Karabakh from its constitution and called Armenia‚Äôs ‚Äòmass militarization‚Äô a major threat to the process. üìç Russian President Vladimir Putin called Azerbaijani President Ilham Aliyev to review the state of ongoing efforts to reach a normalization deal. üìç Opposition leader Bagrat Galstanyan confirmed he is planning to resume protests against Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan next month. üìç An appeals court shortened the detention period of former government minister and Pashinyan critic Armen Ashotyan, raising expectations he may be released imminently.

entry.title: The Russian Revolution and the Making of a Self-Denying Empire

media:group.media:title: The Russian Revolution and the Making of a Self-Denying Empire
media:group.media:description:
Historians Sheila Fitzpatrick and Ronald Grigor Suny deliver a lecture on class and nationality in the Russian Empire at a symposium organized by the Monterey Initiative in Russian Studies at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies at Monterey. The lecture took place on July 1 in Yerevan.
Sheila Fitzpatrick is an Australian historian renowned for her expertise on Soviet and modern Russian history, particularly during Joseph Stalin‚Äôs rule.
Ronald Grigor Suny is a distinguished professor of history at the University of Michigan and emeritus professor of political science and history at the University of Chicago This year‚Äôs Monterey Summer Symposium on Russia took place in Yerevan, Tbilisi, and Istanbul from July 1 to July 20.

entry.title: Armenia‚Äôs main opposition group still backs Bagrat Galstanyan

media:group.media:title: Armenia‚Äôs main opposition group still backs Bagrat Galstanyan
media:group.media:description:
üìç An investigation by the news site Hetq found apparent conflicts of interest with senior government officials around Armenian Public Television‚Äôs move this year to set up an English-language subsidiary in the United States. The government denies wrongdoing. üìç Armenia‚Äôs main opposition bloc, the Armenia Alliance, has reiterated its support for Bagrat Galstanyan, the archbishop-turned-protest leader, who has indicated plans to organize more demonstrations in Yerevan next month after a summer hiatus.

entry.title: EU monitors patrol the Armenia-Azerbaijan border

media:group.media:title: EU monitors patrol the Armenia-Azerbaijan border
media:group.media:description:
CivilNet takes you to the Armenia-Azerbaijan border with monitors from the European Union Mission in Armenia to see their work first hand in the fragile area. The mission was deployed last year at Armenia‚Äôs request in the wake of repeated cross-border attacks by Azerbaijan. Besides reporting the facts on the ground to Brussels, the mission strives to decrease tensions for those living near the border who are impacted by the conflict every day.

entry.title: Red Cross pays latest visit to Armenians illegally detained in Azerbaijan

media:group.media:title: Red Cross pays latest visit to Armenians illegally detained in Azerbaijan
media:group.media:description:
üìç Staff at the International Committee of the Red Cross visited Armenians detained in Azerbaijan, giving them the opportunity to communicate with their relatives. üìç Armenia‚Äôs prime minister and president met with the country‚Äôs diplomats posted around the world as the country continues what appears to be an accelerating turn to the West. üìç Exploring Yerevan‚Äôs ‚Äòbiography‚Äô with Mark Grigoryan: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S35tYMaKv5Q üìç Business Week Armenia: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fbonQDiuWg8

media:group.media:title: Exploring Yerevan‚Äôs ‚Äòbiography‚Äô with Mark Grigoryan
media:group.media:description:
Mark Grigoryan, a journalist, author, and the former director of Armenia‚Äôs National Museum of Architecture, speaks about Yerevan‚Äôs evolution over the millennia at a symposium organized by the Monterey Initiative in Russian Studies at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies at Monterey. Grigoryan‚Äôs speech took place on July 3, in Yerevan. This year‚Äôs Monterey Summer Symposium on Russia took place in Yerevan, Tbilisi, and Istanbul from July 1 to July 20, 2024.

entry.title: Iranian filmmaker Jafar Panahi speaks at Golden Apricot film festival in Yerevan

media:group.media:title: Iranian filmmaker Jafar Panahi speaks at Golden Apricot film festival in Yerevan
media:group.media:description:
In a rare public appearance, renowned Iranian filmmaker and screenwriter Jafar Panahi sits down with Russian film critic Anton Dolin and attendees at this year‚Äôs Golden Apricot International Film Festival in Yerevan, Armenia. Panahi fields audience questions on the art of filmmaking amid state censorship and his experience in prison in Iran. Panahi was recognized as a guest of honor at this year‚Äôs Golden Apricot, marking his first festival visit after 14 years of imprisonment and house arrest in Iran.

entry.title: No official complaints from Russia over brandy quality, Armenia says: THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS

media:group.media:title: No official complaints from Russia over brandy quality, Armenia says: THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS
media:group.media:description:
üìç Armenia said it has not received any official complaints from Russia about the quality of the country‚Äôs multimillion-dollar brandy exports, after Moscow-based consumer rights and lobbying groups claimed the spirits do not meet international safety standards. üìç Washington told CivilNet it is studying a request by Yerevan to reach a Section 123 Agreement, which would pave the way for the United States to design and build a new nuclear power plant in Armenia to replace the country‚Äôs aging facility at Metsamor. Read more: https://shorturl.at/CFsz4 üìç Armenia revised down its GDP growth figure for last year to 8.3% from 8.7%, shaving off some $134 million in value from its original estimate. Armenia also revised down its GDP growth figure for the first quarter of this year to 6.6% from 9.2%. That means Armenia‚Äôs economy is not on track to meet the government‚Äôs target of 7% growth for this year.
